data.title: METALLURG MAGNITOGORSK HOPES TO SIGN MALKIN
data.meta_description: * ITEM: RUSSIAN HOCKEY SUITOR REVEALS ITSELF. . . . PLUS HEMSKY ON ROLLERBLADES.
data.text:
Article content

* ITEM: RUSSIAN HOCKEY SUITOR REVEALS ITSELF. . . . PLUS HEMSKY ON ROLLERBLADES.

Metallurg Magnitogorsk is the Russian club that has made the often-debated offer to Evgeni Malkin of the Pittsburgh Penguins, says Uncle Pedro, the Euro-hockey expert.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

METALLURG MAGNITOGORSK HOPES TO SIGN MALKIN Back to video

“Gennady Velichkin, the club’s president, has admitted as much in a conversation with a Russian journalist … He wouldn’t debate the amount, but said it was more than comparable to what the NHL club can offer … Besides, he said, the new Continental league has sufficient financial backing to compete with the NHL so far as financial compensation goes, with no such concerns as a salary cap …

Article content

“In addition, Velichkov said, the club wants Malkin back, and they want him back now, and who cares about the player’s NHL contract, which runs for one more season … The irony here is that it was Magnitogorsk that Malkin had defected from, citing then-existing stipulations in Russian labour laws that allowed him to give a two-week notice and walk away … That’s why U.S. courts sided with the NHL when the Russians sued … Velichkin went on to shrug off a comment by IIHF president Rene Fasel who had said that anyone who wouldn’t honour another league’s contract would be dishonoured within the IIHF … Meanwhile, Ales Hemsky represents the Czech republic at the in-line hockey world championships, staged by the IIHF at Bratislava … his goal, with his brother Petr adding another, helped his team defeat Germany, 7-6, in the preliminary group, and proceed straight to the final group …”

* BEST OF THE HOCKEYNET: MATT FENWICK AT BATTLE OF ALBERTA

Flames observer Matt Fenwick weighs in on Alex Tanguay’s depature today.

Fenwick’s main point: “The Flames no longer have a second line. The three players who made it up are either traded (Tanguay) or unlikely to return as UFAs (Conroy, Nolan), and there is very little reason to believe that this hole can be filled internally.”

Fenwick adds, “Alex Tanguay is a terrific player who is not easily replaceable, and I am certain that he will be missed. I was glad to get to know him as a hockey player, and hope he does well in Montreal — I couldn’t agree more that he’s just what the doctor ordered for those guys.

As I said, the Flames moves on draft day sounded like good news for Oilers fans. That said, Tanguay wanted to be traded, so the Flames had little choice but to move the guy and get as good as they could for him in return, not unlike has happened here in Edmonton when certain star players wanted out of town.
